THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Monroe Roger Rudd, II,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3663
Heard June 10, 2003 â€“ Filed August 4, 
  2003Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South 
  Carolina Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles 
  H. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Walter M. Bailey, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Monroe Roger Rudd, II, was 
  convicted of committing a lewd act on a child.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial 
  court erred in overruling defense counselâ€™s objections to statements made by 
  the solicitor during closing arguments. We reverse.
FACTS
Rudd lived with Mother and 
  her eight-year-old daughter, Victim, for approximately seven years.Â  Motherâ€™s 
  job often required her to work the night shift, leaving Rudd to care for Victim.Â  
  Victim testified that one evening, when Rudd and Victim were alone together, 
  Rudd asked her to rub his head, which she did.Â  Rudd then allegedly pushed her 
  hand down to his chest and to his stomach.Â  She stated: â€œAnd he kept pushing 
  . . . my hand to his private part and then I felt it.â€ 
Victim also testified that in separate incidents 
  Rudd had her completely disrobe and lie down on the bathroom floor before getting 
  into the shower.Â  She stated that Rudd asked her to spread her legs while he 
  examined her genitals without penetrating her vagina.Â  Victim testified that 
  Ruddâ€™s fingernails were painful to her.Â  According to Victim, Rudd told her 
  that he was examining her in an effort to determine whether she had developed 
  an infection.Â  Rudd allegedly performed these examinations approximately 
  twice a week.Â  
Finally, Victim testified that Rudd had showered 
  with her on a prior occasion.Â  She stated that both she and Rudd were naked 
  at the time.Â  She testified that Rudd helped her wash and rinse her hair because 
  she had difficulty rinsing out all of the shampoo.Â Â  
On March 6, 2001, Victim reported to school officials 
  that Rudd had sexually assaulted her between the months of December 2000 and 
  January 2001.Â  Mother was called to the school and was present when Victim 
  disclosed the alleged misconduct. 
The State charged Rudd with first-degree 
  criminal sexual conduct with a minor as well as committing a lewd act upon a 
  child.Â  At trial, several of the Stateâ€™s witnesses testified that Victim told 
  them identical stories of the circumstances surrounding the alleged assaults.Â  
  Mother testified that she learned of the assaults from Victim when she arrived 
  at the school where Victim first raised the allegations.Â  Later that day, Victim 
  affirmed her account of the alleged assaults while speaking with Patrolman Hubert 
  Prince of the Dorchester County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  Detective Thomas Marshall 
  also testified that Victimâ€™s reports to him were consistent with her earlier 
  accounts to Patrolman Prince, Mother, and an account appearing in the Low Country 
  Childrenâ€™s Center reports.Â  Victimâ€™s grandmother testified Victim told her about 
  the sexual assaults, and it appeared that Victim was consistent in recalling 
  the circumstances surrounding the incidents.Â  Several healthcare professionals 
  also testified that Victim related to them the same specifics of the alleged 
  assaults.Â  
At trial, Rudd testified in his 
  defense.Â  He admitted having washed Victimâ€™s hair, but claimed only to have 
  been treating her for head lice.Â  He also testified to examining Victimâ€™s genitals 
  after she allegedly injured herself on a bicycle seat.Â  However, Rudd denied 
  ever being nude with Victim in the shower and he denied touching her improperly.Â  
  Rudd also denied putting Victimâ€™s hand on his genitals.
At issue in this case 
  are two separate comments made by the solicitor during her closing argument 
  before the jury.Â  First, the solicitor began her closing argument by stating:

Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, the defenseâ€™s argument is 
  what we call the old cotton candy defense. . . . Reminds you of going to the 
  fair when youâ€™re a child, you see the cotton candy, it looks nice and sweet 
  and something good.Â  When you get right down to it basically itâ€™s a lot of sugar 
  spun up with hot air.

Ruddâ€™s counsel objected to this comment as improper 
  and as â€œa scurrilous, at home and personal attack against opposing counsel.â€Â  
  The trial court overruled the objection.
At a later point in her closing argument, the solicitor 
  told the jury:

A child is not sophisticated enough to fool everybody, ladies 
  and gentlemen.Â  The defendant has had many protections before he gets into this 
  court of law to face you jurors.Â  First of all, [Victim] would have to fool 
  Deputy Prince, Lowcountry Childrenâ€™s Center, [and] Detective Marshall, who gets 
  a warrant, has a magistrate sign a warrant.Â  Thereâ€™s a preliminary hearing before 
  a magistrate before its bound over, thereâ€™s a grand jury that true bills or 
  no bills an indictment before this case is ever brought to you.Â  So certainly 
  a childâ€™s story -- a child is not sophisticated enough to fool all these people. 


Defense counsel objected, arguing the solicitor had improperly 
  commented on prior procedures.Â  The trial court again overruled counselâ€™s objection.Â  

The jury acquitted Rudd of first-degree criminal 
  sexual conduct with a minor, but convicted him of committing a lewd act upon 
  a child. Â Rudd was sentenced to a term of twelve years in prison. Â This 
  appeal follows.
ISSUES

  I.                   
  Did the trial court err in determining the solicitorâ€™s statement, which compared 
  the defenseâ€™s argument to cotton candy, did not amount to an improper personal 
  attack on defense counsel?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial 
  court err in determining the solicitorâ€™s reference to prior procedures did not 
  improperly reference preliminary determinations of fact?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The appropriateness of a solicitorâ€™s closing argument 
  is a matter left to the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion. State v. Copeland, 
  321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624 (1996).Â  An appellate court will not 
  disturb a trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding closing argument unless there is an 
  abuse of that discretion. State v. Penland, 275 S.C. 537, 539, 273 S.E.2d 
  765, 766 (1981). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.
Rudd argues that the solicitorâ€™s 
  comparison of Ruddâ€™s defense to cotton candy amounted to an improper personal 
  attack on defense counsel.Â  Accordingly, Rudd insists the trial court erred 
  in overruling defense counselâ€™s objection to the statement. We disagree.
A solicitorâ€™s closing argument 
  must be carefully tailored so it does not appeal to the personal biases of the 
  jurors.Â  Copeland, 321 S.C. at 324, 468 S.E.2d at 624; State v. Linder, 
  276 S.C. 304, 312, 278 S.E.2d 335, 339 (1981). Further, the argument must not 
  be calculated to arouse the jurorsâ€™ passions or prejudices, and its content 
  should stay within the record and reasonable inferences to it.Â  Simmons v. 
  State, 331 S.C. 333, 338, 503 S.E.2d 164, 166 (1998).Â  It is improper for 
  the solicitor to express before the jury his or her personal judgment about 
  opposing counsel.Â  State v. Lunsford, 318 S.C. 241, 246-47, 456 S.E.2d 
  918, 922 (Ct. App. 1995).
Here, the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  by overruling Ruddâ€™s objection to the solicitorâ€™s comparison of Ruddâ€™s defense 
  to cotton candy.Â  The solicitor is entitled, within reason, to question the 
  credibility of Ruddâ€™s defense.Â  See Lunsford, 318 S.C. at 246, 
  456 S.E.2d at 922 (â€œIn telling the jury, â€˜so donâ€™t fall for that,â€™ the solicitor 
  was merely telling the jury that it should not credit defense counselâ€™s argument 
  regarding the absence of fingerprint evidence.â€).Â  Counsel may fairly point 
  out matters that the jury should not consider.Â  Id.Â Â Â  In Ruddâ€™s case, 
  the solicitorâ€™s comment did not express her personal judgment about defense 
  counsel; rather, her statement merely invited the jury to find Ruddâ€™s assertions 
  at trial lacked credibility.Â  
II.
Rudd next contends the solicitorâ€™s reference 
  to prior procedures constituted an improper reference to preliminary determinations 
  of fact.Â  We agree.
Our supreme court has repeatedly 
  condemned closing arguments that lessen the juryâ€™s sense of responsibility by 
  referencing preliminary determinations of the facts.Â  See, e.g., State 
  v. Thomas, 287 S.C. 411, 412, 339 S.E.2d 129 (1986) (citing Thompson 
  v. Aiken, 281 S.C. 239, 315 S.E.2d 110 (1984)); State v. Sloan, 278 
  S.C. 435, 298 S.E.2d 92 (1982); State v. Woomer, 277 S.C. 170, 284 S.E.2d 
  357 (1981)).Â  â€œThese statements to the jury are improper because they inject 
  an arbitrary factor into jury deliberations.Â  The danger is that a juror might 
  be persuaded to rely on the opinion of others instead of exercising his independent 
  judgment as to the facts. . . .â€Â  Thomas, 287 S.C. at 412-13, 339 S.E.2d 
  at 129.
Here, the solicitor told the jury that 
  Rudd â€œhas had many protections before he gets into this court of law to face 
  you jurors.â€Â  The solicitor then informed the jury that, in addition to numerous 
  others who had examined Victimâ€™s allegations, a preliminary hearing was held 
  before a magistrate, and the case had been presented to a grand jury.Â  It is 
  irrelevant that the solicitorâ€™s intent may have been to simply emphasize that 
  Victimâ€™s story had remained consistent throughout the investigation.Â  A statement 
  of this type could have improperly lessened a jurorâ€™s sense of responsibility 
  to independently determine the facts of this case by permitting him or her to 
  rely on the opinions of the investigators, the magistrate, and the grand jury.Â  
  See Thomas, 287 S.C. at 412, 339 S.E.2d at 129 (condemning solicitorâ€™s 
  comment that the case had already been examined by a magistrate and a grand 
  jury, and that a preliminary hearing had been held).Â  Accordingly, we hold the 
  trial court abused its discretion by overruling Ruddâ€™s objection to this improper 
  statement.Â  
However, improper comments do not require reversal 
  if they are not prejudicial to the defendant.Â  Johnson v. State, 325 
  S.C. 182, 187, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  On appeal, an appellate court will 
  review the alleged impropriety of the solicitorâ€™s argument in the context of 
  the entire record, including whether the trial judgeâ€™s instructions adequately 
  cured the improper argument and whether there is overwhelming evidence of the 
  defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  Copeland, 321 S.C. at 324, 468 S.E.2d at 624-25; 
  State v. Johnson, 293 S.C. 321, 326, 360 S.E.2d 317, 320 (1987).Â  The 
  appropriate determination is whether the solicitorâ€™s comment so infected the 
  trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  
  State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997). 
Victim alone provided the substantive 
  testimony against Rudd.Â  The Stateâ€™s other witnesses testified only that Victim 
  told them about the assaults and that her account was consistent as to the time 
  and place the events allegedly occurred.Â  Rudd denied sexually assaulting Victim 
  and testified that he only examined her to determine if she was injured in a 
  bicycle accident.Â  The juryâ€™s verdict ultimately depended upon whether they 
  believed Victimâ€™s story was credible.Â  Under these circumstances, the evidence 
  of Ruddâ€™s guilt is not overwhelming; thus, we find the solicitorâ€™s comment was 
  unfairly prejudicial to Rudd. [1] 
  Â Â  As the supreme court has warned: â€œWe caution solicitors that arguments 
  of this kind can rarely be harmless.â€Â  Thomas, 287 S.C. at 413, 339 S.E.2d 
  at 129.
Moreover, we do not believe the trial courtâ€™s jury charge 
  cured the error.Â  The trial court instructed the jurors to decide the case according 
  to the testimony of sworn witnesses and other evidence without regard to any 
  arbitrary factors.Â  However, the trial court made no reference to the solicitorâ€™s 
  comment regarding the â€œmany protectionsâ€ Rudd had received prior to the trial 
  or the prior examinations by the magistrate, the grand jury, and others.Â  The 
  trial courtâ€™s instruction to the jury was insufficient to cure the solicitorâ€™s 
  improper comment.Â  Considering the solicitorâ€™s closing argument in the context 
  of the entire record, we cannot say the trial courtâ€™s error in allowing the 
  solicitorâ€™s improper comment was harmless. 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Ruddâ€™s conviction 
  is
REVERSED. 
CONNOR and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  The State submits that because the jurors acquitted Rudd of the 
    CSC charge, they could not have been prejudicially affected by the solicitorâ€™s 
    comments.Â  We find this argument unpersuasive.Â  It is impossible for this 
    court to determine what effect the solicitorâ€™s comment may have had on the 
    minds of the jurors.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Harold Pittman,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
C. E. Lowther,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
Gerald C. Smoak, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3669
Heard March 12, 2003 â€“ Filed August 4, 2003

REVERSED


  
    
      
H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Darrell T. Johnson, Jr., of Hardeeville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  C. E. Lowther appeals the 
  order of the circuit court granting a private prescriptive easement across his 
  land to Harold Pittman.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Weldon Wall purchased Good Hope Plantation 
  from Good Hope Corporation.Â  At that time, a very old system of trails and plantation 
  roads traversed the entire tract.Â  One such plantation road was Wellington Road, 
  leading into the plantation from U.S. Highway 278.Â  The entire road system was 
  shown on the plat referenced in the deed.Â  In 1973, Wall subdivided Good Hope 
  into two parcels:Â  Parcel A consisting of 2,340.8 acres and Parcel B containing 
  661.33 acres.Â  Wall sold Parcel A to Pittman.Â  The plat referenced in this deed 
  did not show Wellington Road or any of the other plantation roads. 
 Mary Wilcox later purchased Parcel B at 
  a foreclosure sale.Â  Wilcox assigned a portion of her bid on Parcel B to Pittman 
  and in 1975 Pittman purchased 279 acres out of Parcel B.Â  Pittman converted 
  a hunting lodge located on the property into a home.Â  This property was referred 
  to in the testimony as the â€œhouse tract.â€Â  On three sides, the â€œhouse tractâ€ 
  was bordered by the 2,340.8 acre parcel already owned by Pittman.Â  The remaining 
  portion of Parcel B, held by Wilcox, abutted the fourth side of the tract.Â  
  The â€œhouse tractâ€ did not abut any public road.Â  Both Parcel A and Wilcoxâ€™s 
  land abutted U.S. Highway 278.Â  
Since May of 1973, Pittman used Wellington 
  Road to travel from Highway 278 to a trailer on Parcel A.Â  At the time he purchased 
  the â€œhouse tractâ€ in 1975, his only access to that property was also Wellington 
  Road. [1] Â  After the 1975 purchase, Pittman continued to use Wellington 
  Road to reach Parcel A and as a driveway to his home on the â€œhouse tract.â€Â  
  A portion of the road passed over Wilcoxâ€™s land before it joined U.S. Highway 
  278.Â  
Wilcox sold her remaining portion of Parcel 
  B consisting of 312.11 acres to Lowther in 1976.Â  About five or six years later, 
  Lowther began to place obstacles in Wellington Road in an effort to close the 
  portion which traversed his property. [2] Â  Pittman either drove around 
  the obstacles or cut or pushed them down to travel the road to Highway 278.Â  
  This scenario was repeated numerous times.Â  
Pittman stopped using the road for approximately 
  four or five months in 1992 while a mutual friend attempted to mediate the dispute.Â  
  After the friend told Pittman his settlement attempts were unsuccessful, Pittman 
  promptly pushed up the wires and cables across the road and continued to travel 
  across it to Highway 278.Â  In the early fall of 1997, Lowther requested his 
  attorney write to Mr. Pittman and instruct him to stay off his property and 
  the disputed section of the road.Â  Pittman ignored the letter and destroyed 
  the barriers blocking the road.Â  Lowther called a deputy sheriff out to observe 
  the damage and instruct Pittman to stay off of his land.Â  This litigation ensued.Â  

 The original Wellington Road and a separate, 
  newer county road, some 200 feet farther up, run roughly parallel to one another 
  leading off Highway 278 into the old Good Hope land and towards the Lowther 
  and Pittman properties.Â  About 300 feet from Highway 278, the new county road 
  merges into the original Wellington Road and runs for some unknown distance 
  to the edge of a particular lot belonging to Lowther.Â  Lowther dedicated this 
  portion of Wellington Road to the county.Â  A final portion of the original road 
  continues on for another 168 feet running along the edge of Lowtherâ€™s property 
  until it meets the gate to Pittmanâ€™s â€œhouse tract.â€Â  It is this last 168 feet 
  of Wellington Road that remains in controversy. [3] Â  
Pittman brought an action to declare an 
  easement by prescription, necessity, or dedication across 168 feet of Wellington 
  Road running through Lowtherâ€™s land.Â  After a bench trial, the court issued 
  an order granting Pittman a private prescriptive easement over Wellington Road 
  providing access to Highway 278 across Lowtherâ€™s property.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Continuous and Uninterrupted Use
Lowther argues the trial court erred in 
  concluding Pittman established a private prescriptive easement because the evidence 
  does not support a factual finding that Pittmanâ€™s adverse use was continuous 
  and uninterrupted.Â  Because the trial court reached inconsistent factual findings, 
  it erred in concluding Pittmanâ€™s use was continuous and uninterrupted during 
  the alleged prescriptive period. [4] 
  Â  
â€œThe determination of the existence of an easement 
  is a question of fact in a law action and subject to an any evidence standard 
  of review when tried by a judge without a jury.â€Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 
  S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).Â  The trial court relied upon the 
  following standard set forth in Morrow v. Dyches, 328 S.C. 522, 492 S.E.2d 
  420, 423 (Ct. App. 1997) to find that Pittman should be granted a prescriptive 
  easement.Â  â€œTo establish a prescriptive easement, one must show:Â  (1) continued 
  use for 20 years, (2) the identity of the thing enjoyed, and (3) use which is 
  adverse or under claim of right. Id.Â  (citing Horry County v. Laychur, 
  315 S.C. 364, 434 S.E.2d 259 (1993)).Â  Laychur, however, emphasized as 
  to the first prerequisite not only that there must be a continued use for twenty 
  years, there must be â€œcontinued and uninterrupted use or enjoyment of 
  the right for a period of 20 years.â€Â  Laychur, 315 S.C. at 368, 434 S.E.2d 
  at 261 (emphasis added). [5] Â  The uninterrupted requirement is the focal 
  point here.Â  
The trial courtâ€™s order stated the only 
  interruption in Pittmanâ€™s use of the challenged portion of Wellington Road was 
  during the failed mediation.Â  However, the court also found Pittman had broken 
  open more than $2,000 worth of barriers costing approximately $200 each â€œexercising 
  his perceived right to use the road.â€Â  The barriers the trial court mentioned 
  were erected by Lowther specifically for the purpose of preventing Pittman from 
  utilizing the roadway, and not merely for Lowtherâ€™s own use or convenience.Â  
  On direct examination, Mr. Pittman was asked if he had used the road uninterruptedly 
  from the time he bought the tract, and he responded, â€œNot completely.â€Â  He stated 
  that five or six years after the Lowthers bought the adjoining property, they 
  started putting obstacles in the way trying to close the road, but that he â€œpushed 
  them down or went around them . . . .â€Â  He also testified the Lowthers later 
  â€œput up gates and put up cables,â€ but after the attempted mediation failed, 
  he pushed down the wire and cable the Lowthers had erected across the road.Â  

Mitchell Lowther testified regarding efforts made 
  to prevent Pittman from using the road.Â  In addition to setting posts and bolting 
  cables across it, the road was plowed every year and planted with rye a couple 
  of years.Â  Lowther testified he tried to be a good neighbor and, when he found 
  Pittman had driven around a cable or pushed a cable down, he would calmly put 
  the cable back up to try to cause as little problem as possible.Â  Nevertheless, 
  he eventually reported Pittmanâ€™s actions to law enforcement and had a deputy 
  come see where Pittman had used his tractor to not only push over posts and 
  cables, but uproot a couple of small trees and scrape the road with his tractor.Â  
  Pittman stipulated that he had done so.Â  
Lowtherâ€™s repeated attempts to prevent Pittman 
  from crossing Lowtherâ€™s land constitute interruptions, however brief, in Pittmanâ€™s 
  use and enjoyment of that portion of Wellington Road.Â  See 25 Am. Jur. 
  2d, Easements Â§ 69 (1996) (â€œAny unambiguous act of the owner of the land 
  which evinces his intention to exclude others from the uninterrupted use of 
  the right claimed breaks its continuity so as to prevent the acquisition of 
  an easement therein by prescription . . . .Â  Though the mere erection of gates 
  by the servient owner for the greater convenience of his operations, and not 
  as a barrier to passage, will not defeat a claim to a prescriptive easement 
  of passage, an easement of way cannot arise by prescription if the owner of 
  the servient estate has habitually broken or interrupted its use at will by 
  the maintenance of gates.â€) (footnotes omitted).Â  Therefore, the trial court 
  erred in concluding Pittman enjoyed uninterrupted adverse use of the land for 
  the 20-year period necessary to establish an easement by prescription.Â  
II.Â  Easement by Dedication
As an alternate sustaining ground, Pittman urges us 
  to find the existence of an easement by dedication.Â  The record is devoid of 
  evidence to support this contention.Â  
â€œIt is generally held that when the owner of land 
  has it subdivided and platted into lots and streets and sells and conveys the 
  lots with reference to the plat, he thereby dedicates said streets to the use 
  of such lot owners, their successors in title, and the public.â€Â  Blue Ridge 
  Realty Co. v. Williamson, 247 S.C. 112, 118, 145 S.E.2d 922, 924-25 (1965).Â  
  â€œTwo elements are required to perfect [public] dedication.Â  First, the owner 
  must express in a positive and unmistakable manner the intention to dedicate 
  his property to public use.Â  Second, there must be acceptance of such property 
  by the public.â€Â  Laychur, 315 S.C. at 368, 434 S.E.2d at 261.Â  However, 
  as between the original landowner and his grantee, the dedication is complete 
  when the conveyance is made.Â  Blue Ridge Realty Co., 247 S.C. at 119, 
  145 S.E.2d at 925.Â  
Pittman does not clearly indicate whether 
  the purported easement by dedication is public or private.Â  However, the distinction 
  is without consequence because there is no evidence any prior landowner intended 
  to dedicate an easement in the use of Wellington Road.Â  Pittman argues the plat 
  referenced in the deed when he purchased the 2,340 acre tract from Wall shows 
  part of Wellington Road, including a part of the 168 feet in dispute.Â  However, 
  as one of Pittmanâ€™s own witnesses testified, the plat created for that sale 
  does not show Wellington Road. Â Nor is it shown on the plat referenced 
  in the deed conveying the 279 acre tract to Pittman.Â  
Two plats in the record do show Wellington Road.Â  
  The first was the one created for and referenced in the conveyance of the entire 
  3,000 acres from Good Hope Corporation to Wall.Â  This plat shows the entire 
  plantationâ€™s road system.Â  However, because the plat was not created as part 
  of a subdivision of the land, the display of the old plantation roads cannot 
  be considered a positive and unmistakable intention to dedicate them to the 
  public.Â  Even though this plat is also referenced in the 2,340 acre deed from 
  Wall to Pittman, the absence of roads on the plat created specifically for that 
  conveyance belies the existence of a dedication of Wellington Road to either 
  the public or Pittman individually.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The second plat that shows Wellington 
  Road was created when Wall was planning to subdivide and sell at auction the 
  land adjoining Pittmanâ€™s 279 acre tract.Â  The auction was held, but Lowther 
  offered more than the combined individual lot bids and thus purchased the entire 
  tract. Â The subdivision was never created.Â  Furthermore, although the 
  plat was referenced in the deed conveying the property to Lowther, the deed 
  specifically states the reference was for the purpose of describing the outside 
  boundaries, and was not intended to suggest a subdivision was being transferred.Â  
  Thus, the existence of this document also falls short of a positive and unmistakable 
  intention to dedicate an easement over Wellington Road.Â  
CONCLUSION
Pittman failed to establish a prescriptive easement 
  in the challenged portion of Wellington Road because his use was not continuous 
  and uninterrupted for the requisite period.Â  Pittman also failed to establish 
  an easement by dedication because the evidence does not demonstrate 
  an express intent by any of the prior landowners to create such.Â  For these 
  reasons, the order on appeal is 
 REVERSED.
CURETON 
  and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The â€œhouse tractâ€ deed granted Pittman an express 20-foot 
    access easement to Highway 278.Â  Pittman never used the easement for a driveway 
    to his home.Â  He testified that he had negotiated for the easement for the 
    sole purpose of getting a mowing machine in behind a fence.Â  Five or six big 
    live oak trees stand in the path of the easement and would have to be felled 
    to create a road.Â  

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Pittman testified that about four or five years after he bought 
    the â€œhouse tractâ€ he built a road from a trailer located on the adjoining 
    Parcel A out to U.S. Highway 278.Â  At some point thereafter he constructed 
    a driveway connecting his home on the â€œhouse tractâ€ to that road.Â  This provided 
    an alternate route at about the time the Lowthers began to obstruct Wellington 
    Road.Â  

 
   [3]
   Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Lowthers 
    are developing a subdivision on their property.Â  The disputed portion of Wellington 
    Road runs across 168.83 feet of a lot designated as lot # 12.Â  

 
   
    [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because we hold Pittman did not enjoy continuous and uninterrupted 
    use of the road segment in question, we need not address Lowtherâ€™s other arguments 
    concerning the existence or extent of the claimed easement.

 
   
    [5]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  See generally Hartley v. John Wesley United Methodist 
    Church of Johns Island, Op. No. 3642 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed May 27, 2003) 
    (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 20 at 19, 22-23), for a discussion as to the discrepancy 
    in the correct standard to apply in determining the existence of an easement 
    by prescription.

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Sue Tennis d/b/a Carousel of Learning, Appellant, 
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Â Opinion No. 3670
  Heard June 11, 2003 â€“ Filed August 11, 2003 

REVERSED and REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Rodney F. Pillsbury, Yacobi & Pillsbury, LLC, of Greenville, for 
          Appellant.
        Rose Mary McGregor, S.C. Dept. of Social Services, of Columbia, for 
          Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Sue Tennis appeals from an 
  order of the circuit court affirming the Department of Social Servicesâ€™ (DSS) 
  denial of her application to renew her license to operate a day care facility.Â  
  We reverse and remand.
FACTS 
Sue Tennisâ€™s history with DSS dates back to 1986.Â  
  In that year, DSS â€œindicated a caseâ€ against Tennis for sexual abuse; that case 
  was ultimately dismissed.Â  In 1991, Tennis applied to DSS for a day care license, 
  which DSS denied.Â  This denial was overturned by the family court in 1992 in 
  an order that stated: â€œDSS did not produce one shred of credible evidence as 
  to why Tennisâ€™s application should be denied.â€ Since that order, Tennis has 
  operated the Carousel of Learning day care facility under a provisional license 
  issued by DSS.Â  Until this action, her provisional license has been renewed 
  each time it expired.Â  
Tennis changed the location of her day care in 
  1995.Â  When she moved, her previous landlord filed charges against her because 
  she removed playground equipment and left behind about a dozen holes on the 
  property.Â Â Â  Tennis pled guilty to malicious injury to property by a tenant, 
  which is a misdemeanor.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§16-11-570 (stating that 
  the injury or destruction of buildings or crops by a tenant is a misdemeanor). 

DSS made unannounced visits to Carousel of Learning 
  on June 4, August 5, and October 9, 1997. No deficiencies were found 
  on any of these visits.Â  On October 13, 1997, DSS sent Tennis a notice, which 
  stated:Â  â€œThe Division of Child Day Care Licensing and Regulatory Services has 
  been notified by the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division that you . . . 
  have been convicted of a crime which prevents employment in a child day care 
  facility.â€Â  DSS was mistaken, however, because the crime to which Tennis pled 
  guilty was a misdemeanor and as such, did not prevent her from employment in 
  a day care facility. [1]  
In December of 1997, DSS visited Carousel of Learning in 
  response to an anonymous complaint.Â  The complaint was not substantiated and 
  no deficiencies were noted.Â  Another unannounced visit was made on February 
  2, 1998.Â  Again, no deficiencies were found.Â  
On May 21, 1998, DSS visited the facility and cited it for three violations:Â  
  (1) having only one caregiver on the premises with 15 children; (2) not designating 
  a director; and (3) failing to meet the fire codes because four infants were 
  in a room not designated for infants.Â  At the time of this visit, DSS was operating 
  under the false assumption that Tennis was a convicted felon who could not work 
  at a day care facility.Â  Thus, even when Tennis was at the facility, she was 
  not counted as a supervisor or counted in the child-to-staff ratios.Â  If Tennis 
  had been present on May 21, the only deficiency would have been the four infants 
  in a non-designated room.Â  
Again on June 23, 1998, DSS made an unannounced 
  visit and found inappropriate ratios.Â  However, Tennis was at the facility that 
  day and was not counted toward these ratios.
On July 24, 1998, Tennis initiated a meeting with 
  DSS in order to clear up the confusion regarding her guilty plea.Â  She brought 
  in papers that listed S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-570 as the statute under which 
  she pled guilty. That statute explicitly states that malicious injury to property 
  by a tenant is a misdemeanor.Â  Despite this meeting, DSS maintained its position 
  that Tennisâ€™s criminal background prevented her from being employed at the day 
  care.Â  
From August of 1998 until November of 1999, DSS 
  made numerous unannounced visits to Tennisâ€™s day care.Â  DSS found no deficiencies 
  on five of those visits. [2] Â  
  On four of the visits in which deficiencies were found, there would have been 
  no deficiency if DSS had counted Tennis toward the child-to-staff ratios. [3] Â  On two visits, however, there were confirmed 
  violations regardless of whether Tennis was counted.Â  These violations occurred 
  on July 15 and July 30, 1999. 
During the July 15, 1999 visit, DSS found two caregivers 
  in one room with twenty-four children.Â  The room was designated for only twelve 
  children.Â  Tennis admitted the violation but explained that her facility was 
  short-handed because an employee had quit unexpectedly.Â  On July 30, 1999, DSS 
  found violations because there were fourteen children in a room designated for 
  twelve, a caregiver did not have her fingerprints on file, no menu was posted, 
  and the sleeping mats were not labeled.Â  DSS also found that there was no designated 
  director and there were inadequate child-to-staff ratios; however, it is unclear 
  whether these violations would have existed had Tennis been counted.Â  In regards 
  to the missing fingerprints, Tennis explained the employee in violation was 
  a recent high school graduate who was enrolled in early childhood development 
  classes at the local community college. To be enrolled in these classes, students 
  needed to submit their fingerprints to SLED, and Tennis assumed that the employee 
  had already been fingerprinted. The employee eventually did submit her fingerprints, 
  and she had no criminal history.
In November of 1999, DSS sent Tennis a letter denying 
  Tennisâ€™s application for renewal of her day care license.Â  The letter listed 
  the following as the basis for denial:

  1. Ms. Sue Tennis, owner of the facility, continues to provide direct care 
    for children after having been notified by certified mail on October 3, 1997 
    (sic) and August 17, 1998, that she had been convicted of a crime which prevented 
    her from employment in a child day care facility per Section 20-7-2725 of 
    the 1976 Code of Laws of South Carolina as amended.
  2. The facility has continued to employ a caregiver, Ms. Wendy Wilson, in 
    direct care of children who failed to undergo a State and Federal fingerprint 
    review in violation of Section 20-7-2740 (F) of the South Carolina Day Care 
    Licensing Law.
  3. The operator has failed to correct deficiencies within the time frames 
    prescribed by the Department after being given timely notice per Section 20-7-2750 
    (D) of the South Carolina Day Care Licensing Law.Â  Inadequate supervision 
    was found on visits by Department staff on February 12, 1997, May 23, 1997, 
    May 21, 1998, June 23, 1998, August 18, 1998, April 12, 1999, July 15, 1999, 
    July 20, 1999, and July 30, 1999.

After sending this letter, DSS made two additional 
  unannounced visits in March and April of 2000, and found no violations on either 
  visit.Â  Finally, on August 16, 2000, a hearing was held.Â  
In the Final Administrative Order, the State Director 
  of DSS found that DSS properly denied the renewal based on the violations from 
  July 15, 1999 and July 30, 1999.Â  The director found the health and safety of 
  the children in the day care were placed in jeopardy by the failure to maintain 
  adequate staffing ratios and the failure to have a caregiver submit to a fingerprint 
  check.Â Â Â  
The circuit court reviewed the case and found that 
  the decision to deny the renewal was based upon â€œinadequate ratios and other 
  regulatory non-compliance issues as noted in the Final Administrative Order.Â  
  On the two dates in question, severe ratio deficiencies were found.â€Â  The court 
  acknowledged that DSS had improperly excluded Tennis when calculating supervision 
  ratios but concluded the â€œagencyâ€™s determination was not tainted by any error 
  of law, was not clearly erroneous in view of the reliable and substantial evidence 
  presented, and was not arbitrary, capricious or an abuse of discretion.â€Â Â  This 
  appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
Under the APA, â€œ[t]his court will not substitute 
  its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions 
  of fact.â€Â  Leventis v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  340 S.C. 118, 130, 530 S.E.2d 643, 649-50 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Ballenger 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 331 S.C. 247, 251, 
  500 S.E.2d 183, 185 (Ct. App. 1998); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (Supp. 2002)).Â  


  We will not overrule an agencyâ€™s decision unless:
  substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative 
    findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are:
  (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
  (b) in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
  (c) made upon unlawful procedure;
  (d) affected by other error of law;
  (e) clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial 
    evidence on the whole record;Â  or
  (f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly 
    unwarranted exercise of discretion.Â  

Leventis, 340 S.C. at 130, 530 S.E.2d at 
  650 (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2002); Ballenger, 
  331 S.C. at 251, 500 S.E.2d at 185). 
â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of 
  evidence nor evidence viewed blindly from one side, but is evidence which, when 
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the 
  conclusion that the agency reached.â€Â  Waters v. South Carolina Land Res. 
  Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 226, 467 S.E.2d 913, 917 (1996) (quoting 
  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 
  430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing two inconsistent 
  conclusions from the evidence will not mean the agency's conclusion was unsupported 
  by substantial evidence.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œFurthermore, the burden is on appellants 
  to prove convincingly that the agency's decision is unsupported by the evidence.â€Â  
  Id. (citing Hamm v. AT&T, 302 S.C. 210, 394 S.E.2d 842 (1990)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Denial of 
  Tennisâ€™s Day Care License Renewal
Tennis maintains there was not substantial evidence 
  to support the directorâ€™s decision not to renew her license.Â  She contends the 
  decision was arbitrary and based upon DSSâ€™s incorrect assumption that she was 
  convicted of a felony.Â  We agree.Â  
Looking at the record as a whole, the overwhelming 
  evidence indicates DSS repeatedly cited Tennis for violations that were not 
  truly violations.Â  Nearly every month for two years, DSS made unannounced visits 
  to the day care center, and several months, DSS visited more than one time.Â  
  These visits were often predicated on DSSâ€™s incorrect assessment that child- 
  to-staff ratios at the facility were inadequate when in fact, if DSS had counted 
  Tennis toward those ratios, there would have been no violation. In light of 
  that error and considering Tennisâ€™s history with DSS, the evidence on the whole 
  record reflects a history of DSSâ€™s bias against Tennis.
In its letter to Tennis notifying her of its decision 
  to deny the renewal of her license, DSS lists Tennisâ€™s status as a felon as 
  its first reason for non-renewal.Â  The record, however, clearly indicates that 
  Tennis was not a felon.
The next reason for denial listed in the letter is 
  the â€œcontinued [employment of] a caregiver . . . in direct care of children 
  who failed to undergo a State and Federal fingerprint review . . . .â€Â  At the 
  hearing, Tennis admitted this violation, explained how it happened, and presented 
  evidence that the caregiver was fingerprinted after she had been cited for this 
  violation.Â  The fingerprinting results revealed the caregiver had no criminal 
  record.Â Â  
Finally, the letter refers to dates upon which DSS 
  made visits and found violations.Â  At least one date listed was not even a day 
  upon which a visit was made, [4]  and a majority of the dates listed 
  would not have been violations if DSS had counted Tennis in its child-to-staff 
  ratios. 
Upon consideration of the entire record, we hold the 
  decision of DSS to deny Tennisâ€™s renewal of her day care license was clearly 
  erroneous in light of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence.Â  In 
  1992, the family court found DSS presented â€œnot one shredâ€ of evidence supporting 
  the denial of Tennisâ€™s license.Â  Since then, it appears DSS has attempted to 
  bolster its case against Tennis by making frequent unannounced visits and repeatedly 
  citing her for violations that did not exist.Â  Based on this history, we do 
  not believe the violations on July 15th and July 30th amount to â€œsubstantialâ€ 
  or â€œreliableâ€ evidence.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Tennis next argues that if the circuit courtâ€™s decision 
  is reversed, she is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to S.C. Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 
  (Supp. 2002).Â  Under that statute, a party defending an action brought by the 
  State may recover attorneyâ€™s fees and costs if three prerequisites are met: 
  first, the contesting party must be the prevailing party; second, the court 
  must find that the agency acted without substantial justification in pressing 
  its claim against the party; and third, the court must find that there are no 
  special circumstances that would make the award of attorney's fees unjust.Â  
  Richland County v. Kaiser, 351 S.C. 89, 96, 567 S.E.2dÂ  260, 264 (Ct. 
  App. 2002).Â  Based on our decision to reverse the denial of Tennisâ€™s day care 
  license and there being no evidence that makes the award of attorneyâ€™s fees 
  unjust, we find Tennis is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees incurred during the litigation 
  pursuant to Â§ 15-77-300. See McDowell v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Servs., 304 S.C. 539, 543, 405 S.E.2d 830, 833 (1991) (finding that although 
  Â§ 15-77-300 entitled appellant to attorneyâ€™s fees for the action for judicial 
  review in circuit court, appellant was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees for the 
  hearing before DSS because â€œthe agency was not â€˜pressing its claimâ€™ in litigation 
  against appellant but was merely functioning as an administrative decision-makerâ€).
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is REVERSED, 
  and we REMAND the case to the circuit court to determine the amount 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees owed.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
CONNOR and STILWELL, J.J. concur.


 
   
    [1]  Section 20-7-2725(A) of the South Carolina Code states: 


  No day care center . . . may employ a person or engage the services 
    of a caregiver . . . who has been convicted of (1) a crime listed in Chapter 
    3 of Title 16, Offenses Against the Person; (2) a crime listed in Chapter 
    15 of Title 16, Offenses Against Morality and Decency; (3) the crime of contributing 
    to the delinquency of a minor contained in Section 16-17-490; (4) the felonies 
    classified in Section 16-1-10(A) . . . ; (5) the offenses enumerated in Section 
    16-1-10(D); or (6) a criminal offense similar in nature to the crimes listed 
    in this subsection committed in other jurisdiction or under federal law.

 
   [2]  The dates of the visits with no deficiencies are: 
    9/1/98, 10/11/98, 5/12/99, 6/2/99, and 6/23/99.

 
   [3]  The dates where there would have been no deficiency 
    if Tennis had been counted are: 9/17/98, 4/12/99, 5/4/99, and 7/20/99.

 
   [4]  In its letter denying Tennisâ€™s license renewal, 
    DSS listed May 23, 1997 as a day upon which a violation was found; however, 
    no visit was made on that date. Instead, DSS received an anonymous complaint 
    on May 23rd, and when DSS followed-up the complaint with a visit on June 4, 
    1997, no deficiencies were found.Â

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Anthony White, Employee, 
          Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Medical University of South 
          Carolina, Employer, and State Accident Fund, Carrier, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston 
  County
  A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3671
  Heard June 25, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  August 11, 2003 

AFFIRMED 


 
   
     
      
        Cynthia B. Polk, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        E. Courtney Gruber and R. 
          Walter Hundely, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, 
  C.J.: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the commission found that Anthony 
  Whiteâ€™s claim was barred by the applicable statute of limitations.Â  White appealed 
  to the circuit court, which reversed the commission, finding Whiteâ€™s claim was 
  not barred by the statute of limitations, and awarded benefits. Whiteâ€™s employer, 
  the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) appeals, arguing the circuit 
  court erred in (1) not dismissing the claim for Whiteâ€™s failure to set forth 
  sufficient grounds for appeal in his petition for judicial review; (2) finding 
  the commissionâ€™s decision was not supported by substantial evidence; and (3) 
  determining that MUSC was estopped from asserting the statute of limitations 
  as a defense.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL 
  HISTORY
White 
  worked at MUSC as an operating room technician/nursing assistant.Â  His job duties 
  included removing trash bins from the operating room, moving equipment, lifting 
  patients, and transporting patients to and from other rooms.Â  Larger patients 
  were transported by way of a 1500- pound bed called a â€œbig-boyâ€ bed.Â  
In 1997, 
  White complained to his supervisor that he had hurt himself, and he sought medical 
  treatment from Dr. G.T. Little, complaining primarily of poor circulation in 
  his legs.Â  Dr. Littleâ€™s notes from that day indicated that White also complained 
  of severe lower back pain; however, the notes further stated that White â€œhad 
  no injuries to the back that [White] is aware of.â€Â  The injury did not prevent 
  White from returning to work, nor was White put on any light duty restrictions 
  or work restrictions. 
The record 
  indicates White went to his family physician, Dr. F.C. Walker, on February 2, 
  1999.Â  Dr. Walker treated White for flu symptoms and noted that White complained 
  â€œof some back pain in the lower thorax.â€Â  White again saw Dr. Walker on February 
  26, 1999, and Dr. Walkerâ€™s notes indicated that White was experiencing some 
  back pain at that time. White also saw Dr. Walker on November 1, 1999, and on 
  that date he complained of muscular thoracic pain.Â  
On April 
  12, 2000, White saw Dr. Elizabeth Rittenberg for low back pain radiating into 
  both legs.Â  In her report, Dr. Rittenberg noted that White had had low back 
  pain for several years but it had gotten worse in the three weeks prior to his 
  visit.Â  In her notes from a visit on April 24, 2000, Dr. Rittenberg stated that 
  an MRI scan of White showed a small midline L4, 5 disc herniation.Â  
White 
  filed a Form 50 seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits on December 6, 2000.Â  
  The single commissioner denied the claim, finding it was barred by the two-year 
  statute of limitations. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-40 (Supp. 2002).Â  The full commission 
  affirmed.Â  White appealed to the circuit court, which reversed and remanded 
  the matter back to the commission.Â  The circuit court found a reasonable person 
  would not have been on notice that he suffered a work-related claim prior to 
  April 2000.Â  Because it found the statute of limitations did not begin to run 
  until that date, the circuit court found Whiteâ€™s claim was not barred. Â The 
  court also found that substantial evidence existed to support Whiteâ€™s position 
  that he suffered a disc herniation as a result of repetitive trauma.Â  MUSC appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 

â€œThe South Carolina Administrative 
  Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions 
  of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.â€Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 
  S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 94-95 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Gibson v. Spartanburg 
  Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000);Â  Hamilton 
  v. Bob Bennett Ford, 336 S.C. 72, 518 S.E.2d 599 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œIn 
  an appeal from the Commission, this Court may not substitute its judgment for 
  that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, 
  but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.â€Â  Corbin, 
  351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95 (citing Hamilton, 336 S.C. at 76, 518 
  S.E.2d at 601).Â Â  â€œThe appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether 
  the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled 
  by some error of law.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe findings of an administrative agency 
  are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial 
  evidence.â€ Id. (citing Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, 335 S.C. 
  46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 
  488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 

I. Sufficiency 
  of Whiteâ€™s Notice of Appeal
MUSC 
  first argues Whiteâ€™s appeal should have been dismissed by the circuit court 
  for failure to set forth sufficient grounds for appeal in his petition for review.Â  
  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â  
The commission adopted the single 
  commissionerâ€™s order, which concluded as a matter of law that White had not 
  met the two-year statute of limitations.Â  The commission thus denied the claim.Â  
  In his notice of appeal, White stated the following exception to the ruling: 
  â€œThe Full Commission erred in finding as a fact and concluding as a matter of 
  law that the Claimant was not entitled to benefits under the South Carolina 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.â€Â  
Section 
  42-17-60 of the South Carolina Code (1985) states that â€œ[n]otice of appeal [to 
  the circuit court from the commission] must state the grounds of the appeal 
  or the alleged errors of law.â€Â  In Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 
  S.C. 518, 415 S.E.2d 841 (Ct. App. 1992), an injured workerâ€™s exception that 
  â€œthe facts found by the commission were not supported by credible evidenceâ€ 
  was specific enough to satisfy the notice requirements of section 42-17-60. 
  [1] Â  Whiteâ€™s exception, attacking the commissionâ€™s findings of fact and 
  conclusions of law, is substantially similar to the one upheld in Solomon.Â  
  
In Whiteâ€™s 
  case, the commissionâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law only addressed 
  the statute of limitations issue; thus, Whiteâ€™s notice of appeal was sufficient 
  to direct the circuit court to the error complained of and allow the court to 
  determine whether the ruling was erroneous.Â  Both the court and MUSC were on 
  notice that White believed the commission erred in finding he was not entitled 
  to benefits.Â  Thus, we find no error.
II. Statute 
  of Limitations
MUSC 
  next argues the circuit court erred in finding the commissionâ€™s decision was 
  not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
The commission 
  found that Whiteâ€™s claim was barred by the statute of limitations because White 
  â€œeither knew or should have known that repetitive lifting of patients and gurneys 
  was causing injury to his back as far back as 1997.â€Â  In reversing the commission, 
  the circuit court found, inter alia, there was substantial evidence to 
  support Whiteâ€™s position that he suffered disc herniation as a result of repetitive 
  trauma.Â  
A repetitive 
  trauma injury has a â€œgradual onset caused by the cumulative effect of repetitive 
  traumatic events or â€˜mini-accidents.â€™â€ Schulknight v. City of N. Charleston, 
  352 S.C. 175, 178, 574 S.E.2d 194, 195 (2002). In Schulknight, a firefighter 
  sought workersâ€™ compensation benefits for hearing loss he suffered from sitting 
  next to the fire siren and air horn while he rode in the fire truck.Â  The firefighter 
  had a hearing test in April of 1995, which indicated he had suffered noise-induced 
  hearing loss.Â  Despite this hearing loss, the doctor administering the test 
  concluded the firefighter could still perform his job.Â  Over the next two years, 
  the firefighter was diagnosed with bilateral hearing loss from noise exposure 
  and was told that in approximately ten years, he would need hearing aids.Â  Id. 
  at 176, 574 S.E.2d at 194-195.Â Â  The firefighter left the fire department in 
  August of 1997, and in May of 1998, he filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
  The full commission found the two-year statute of limitations had run because 
  the firefighter knew he had work-induced hearing loss since May of 1995.Â  Id. 
  at 177, 574 S.E.2d at 195.Â  The supreme court reversed, finding the firefighterâ€™s 
  injury was caused by repetitive trauma.Â  The court noted that â€œit is difficult 
  to determine the date an accident occurs in a repetitive trauma case because 
  there is no definite time of injury.â€ Â Id.Â  The court went on to â€œhold 
  the last day of exposure is the date from which the statute of limitations begins 
  to run in a repetitive trauma case.â€Â  Id. at 179, 574 S.E.2d at 196.Â Â  
  
In the present case, although White 
  complained of back pain in 1997, his injury was not severe enough at that time 
  to warrant any change to his duties at work. As White continued to lift heavy 
  equipment and patients at work, his back pain worsened, and eventually, he was 
  diagnosed with a disc herniation and ordered not to lift heavy objects.  [2] Â  Thus, even if substantial evidence supported 
  the commissionâ€™s determination that White knew since 1997 that his back pain 
  was work-related, the statute of limitations did not begin to run until the 
  last day of exposure - Whiteâ€™s last day of work in April of 2000. Id.Â  
  
We agree with the circuit court that 
  substantial evidence supports the finding that Whiteâ€™s injury was the result 
  of repetitive trauma, which arose out of and in the course of Whiteâ€™s employment.Â  
  Thus, the circuit court correctly found that the statute of limitations had 
  not run and White is entitled to workersâ€™ compensation benefits. [3] Â  See also Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack 
  Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 416 S.E.2d 639 (1992) (stating that the policy in South 
  Carolina is to liberally construe the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act in favor of 
  coverage); Gattis v. Chavez, 413 F. Supp. 33, 39 (D.S.C. 1976) (â€œStatutes 
  of limitation which are susceptible to judicial construction should not be applied 
  mechanically but rather construed in the manner most consistent with both their 
  underlying purposes and the requirements of substantial justice for all parties 
  involved.â€)Â  
Accordingly, 
  based on the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
CURETON and STILWELL, J.J. concur.Â  
  

 
   
    [1]  Solomonâ€™s other two exceptions, that the â€œdecision of the commission 
    failed to address all the exceptions and points of law brought before the 
    commissionâ€ and â€œupon such further exception as will hereafter be served,â€ 
    were not sufficient to satisfy the notice requirements of section 42-17-60. 
    Solomon, 307 S.C. at 522, 415 S.E.2d at 844.

 
   
    [2]  According to Dr. Rittenberg, â€œwithin a reasonable degree of medical 
    certainty . . . [Whiteâ€™s] job duties [were] of such a nature that they could 
    have aggravated or exacerbated his pre-existing chronic back pain [from 1997], 
    ultimately resulting in disc herniation.â€ 

 
   [3]  Because we find the statute of limitations has 
    not run, we need not address the issue of estoppel.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Patsy Ann Gilbert, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Marvin Miller and Toya Abbatiello, Defendants,
Of whom Toya Abbatiello is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3672
Submitted April 7, 2003 â€“ Filed August 18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James H. Price, III, and H.W. Pat Paschal, Jr., both of Greenville, 
  for Appellant.
Matthew K. Johnson, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CONNOR, J.:  Patsy Ann Gilbert filed 
  suit against Marvin Miller and Millerâ€™s landlord, Toya Abbatiello, to recover 
  for personal injuries sustained by Gilbert after being bitten by Millerâ€™s dog.Â  
  Abbatiello filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  The 
  trial court granted Abbatielloâ€™s motion.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Miller resides with his dog at an apartment complex 
  owned by Abbatiello.Â  Millerâ€™s dog attacked Gilbert while she was visiting at 
  another tenantâ€™s apartment. [1]  
 

Gilbert filed suit against Miller and Abbatiello.Â  
  Gilbert alleged in her complaint that Abbatiello was negligent in â€œallowing 
  Miller to keep a vicious dog on her premises despite . . . a policy of no dogs 
  kept by tenants except for small dogs.â€Â  The complaint did not refer to any 
  lease agreement and did not allege any duty on the part of Abbatiello.
Abbatiello moved to dismiss the complaint against 
  her based on Gilbertâ€™s failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause 
  of action upon which relief can be granted.Â  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  The trial 
  court granted Abbatielloâ€™s motion.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Gilbert correctly asserts 
  the trial court converted Abbatielloâ€™s Rule 12(b)(6) motion into a motion for 
  summary judgment by reviewing matters outside of the pleadings.Â  The trial courtâ€™s 
  order referred to Abbatielloâ€™s motion as a motion to dismiss pursuant Rule 12(b)(6), 
  SCRCP.Â  A Rule 12(b)(6) motion is converted to a Rule 56, SCRCP, motion for 
  summary judgment if â€œmatters outside the pleading are presented to and not excluded 
  by the Court . . . .â€Â  Rule 12(b), SCRCP.Â  
Gilbert submitted affidavits, photographs, and 
  a copy of the lease agreement in her response to Abbatielloâ€™s motion.Â  Abbatiello 
  did not object to their inclusion and the trial court specifically mentioned 
  the lease agreement and Patsy Chambersâ€™ affidavit in its order.Â  Therefore, 
  Abbatielloâ€™s Rule 12(b)(6) motion was converted to a motion for summary judgment.Â  
  See Benson v. United Guar. Residential Ins. of Iowa, 315 S.C. 
  504, 445 S.E.2d 647 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding where the trial court considers 
  matters outside the pleadings the motion to dismiss is converted to one for 
  summary judgment).
When reviewing a dismissal of an action under Rule 
  56, SCRCP, an appellate court applies the same standard of review implemented 
  by the trial court.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002).Â  
  A trial courtâ€™s decision to grant a motion for summary judgment is appropriate 
  only when there is no genuine issue of material fact so that the moving party 
  is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, 
  and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed against the movant.Â  
  Id.Â Â  
Â LAW/ANALYSIS
A.
Gilbert argues the trial court erred by dismissing 
  her complaint on the basis that a landlord is not liable for injuries caused 
  by a tenantâ€™s dog kept on leased premises.
In Mitchell v. Bazzle, 304 S.C. 402, 404 
  S.E.2d 910 (Ct. App. 1991), we first addressed a landlordâ€™s liability for injuries 
  inflicted by a tenantâ€™s dog.Â  The â€œclear questionâ€ presented in Mitchell 
  was whether South Carolina law â€œimposed a duty on [landlord] to [plaintiff] 
  to terminate [tenant]â€™s month-to-month lease in order to remove [tenant]â€™s dog 
  from the land.â€Â  Id. at 404, 404 S.E.2d at 911.Â  We held a landlord could 
  not be vicariously liable under the common law for the actions of a tenantâ€™s 
  dog even where the landlord knew of the animalâ€™s vicious propensities and could 
  have foreseen the injury, had adequate time to terminate a month-to-month tenancy, 
  and failed to terminate the lease.Â  Id. at 404-05, 404 S.E.2d at 911-12. [2] Â  
In Fair v. United States, 334 S.C. 321, 
  513 S.E.2d 616 (1999), our Supreme Court analyzed the question of whether the 
  South Carolina Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (RLTA) 
  [3]  altered the common law rule espoused in Mitchell.Â  The Court 
  held that under the RLTA a landlord is liable only for defects relating to the 
  inherent physical state of the leased premises.Â  Fair, 334 S.C. at 323-24, 
  513 S.E.2d at 617.Â  Therefore, the RTLA â€œdoes not alter the common law rule 
  that a landlord is not liable to a tenantâ€™s invitee for injury caused by a tenantâ€™s 
  dog.â€Â  Id.; see Bruce v. Durney, 341 S.C. 563, 534 S.E.2d 
  720 (Ct. App. 2000) (recognizing and reaffirming the principle of law stated 
  in Fair and Mitchell).
Since there is no dispute over any material facts, 
  the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment.Â  Abbatiello was entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law because South Carolina law does not recognize 
  holding a landlord vicariously liable for the actions of a tenantâ€™s dog.
B.
However, this does not end the inquiry.Â  
  Gilbert also contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment for 
  Abbatiello because the lease agreement between Abbatiello and Miller created 
  a duty of care for the landlord to prevent harm by a tenantâ€™s dog.Â  See 
  Miller v. City of Camden, 317 S.C. 28, 451 S.E.2d 401 (Ct. App. 1994), 
  affâ€™d as modified, 329 S.C. 310, 494 S.E.2d 813 (1997) (stating an affirmative 
  legal duty to act can exist if created by contract).Â  The lease provided:

Pets must meet the approval of 
  the landlord and appropriate additional deposits may be required.Â  Dogs will 
  not be allowed in multifamily units.Â  Continuous disturbances or complaints, 
  such as odors, fleas or messes caused by the pet, will result in the deposit 
  being forfeited along with additional monies to correct the problems and the 
  animal must leave the premises.Â  If it is necessary to hire a pest eradicator 
  because of a flea problem the tenant will pay the cost.Â  The tenant will also 
  be responsible for any damage caused by the pet and must be in full control 
  of the pet at all times.

Initially, Gilbert did not allege, and there is 
  no evidence in the record, she entered into a lease agreement like the one between 
  Abbatiello and Miller.Â  Thus, in the absence of any allegation that Gilbert 
  entered into an identical lease, it is impossible to say, as Gilbert claims 
  in her brief, the â€œlease could be relied upon by other tenants in entering their 
  lease as assurance that their premises (and guests) would be free of the presence 
  ofâ€ a vicious dog.Â Â  See Bob Hammond Const. Co. v. Banks Const. Co., 
  312 S.C. 422, 440 S.E.2d 890 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating a third person not in 
  privity of contract with the contracting parties generally may not enforce the 
  provisions of a contract unless it is entered into for the benefit of the third 
  person).Â Â Â Â Â  
This Court dealt with the creation 
  of a duty by a lease in Goode v. St. Stephens United Methodist Church, 
  329 S.C. 433, 494 S.E.2d 827 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Goode was attacked while visiting 
  a friend at an apartment complex.Â  One of his attackers resided at the apartment 
  complex.
Goode sued the landlord (St. 
  Stephens) asserting St. Stephens was negligent in failing to provide security.Â  
  Goode alleged he was a third party beneficiary under the lease agreement in 
  which tenants agreed not to engage in unlawful conduct on the grounds of the 
  apartment complex.Â  Thus, Goode argued the lease created a duty for St. Stephens 
  to protect him from attack by third parties.Â  Id. at 445, 494 S.E.2d 
  at 833.Â  
Upon examination of the lease 
  provision, we concluded St. Stephens did not owe a duty of care to Goode because 
  he was not a third party beneficiary under the contract.Â  We concluded that 
  if St. Stephens did not â€œcovenant to prevent or to protect tenants from 
  the violent acts of other tenants or third partiesâ€ it surely â€œcould not have 
  intended to create such a benefit directly in favor of Goode.â€Â  Id. at 
  446, 494 S.E.2d at 833. 
The main guide in contract interpretation is to 
  ascertain and give legal effect to the intentions of the parties as expressed 
  in the language of the lease.Â  United Dominion Realty Trust, Inc. v. Wal-Mart 
  Stores, Inc., 307 S.C. 102, 413 S.E.2d 866 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  If a contractâ€™s 
  language is clear and capable of legal construction, this Courtâ€™s function is 
  to interpret its lawful meaning and the intent of the parties as found in the 
  agreement.Â  Smith-Cooper v. Cooper, 344 S.C. 289, 543 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  A clear and explicit contract must be construed according to the 
  terms the parties have used, with the terms to be taken and understood in their 
  plain, ordinary, and popular sense.Â  Sphere Drake Ins. Co. v. Litchfield, 
  313 S.C. 471, 438 S.E.2d 275 (Ct. App. 1993).Â Â  
It is clear the language of the 
  lease did not intend to make Gilbert, as either a tenant or a guest, a third 
  party beneficiary by imposing a duty in tort on the landlord to prevent a tenantâ€™s 
  dog from injuring another.Â  The lease provision cannot be construed as being 
  for the protection of other tenants or guests.Â  A review of the lease provision 
  shows its primary purpose was to prevent damage to the property or disruption 
  of the physical habitability of the apartment complex by a tenantâ€™s pet.Â  This 
  is evident from the provisionâ€™s use of the general term â€œpetsâ€ rather than â€œdogs.â€ 
  [4] Â  This provision could refer to any pet, not only dogs, and demonstrates 
  Abbatiello did not contract to protect others from dogs on the premises.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

The lease provisionâ€™s concern 
  rested in ensuring any tenant who kept a pet would be responsible for any mess 
  or sanitary problems caused by the animal.Â  Importantly, the lease explicitly 
  made the control of the pet the sole responsibility of the tenant, not the landlord.Â  
  See Braun v. York Props., Inc., 583 N.W.2d 503 (Mich. Ct. App. 
  1998) (finding landlord had no duty to protect others from attack by a tenantâ€™s 
  dog even where landlord had promulgated rules and regulations governing tenantsâ€™ 
  possession of dogs; the primary purpose of the rules was to protect against 
  harm to the premises); cf. Alaskan Village, Inc. v. Smalley, 720 
  P.2d 945 (Alaska 1986) (finding landlord had undertaken a specific duty to protect 
  others from tenantâ€™s vicious dog and could be found liable where lease specifically 
  prohibited tenants from keeping â€œvicious dogsâ€).Â  
The landlord here has not contracted 
  to remove pets unless there have been continuous disturbances or complaints.Â  
  Abbatiello had not received any complaints about Millerâ€™s dog other than her 
  own observation â€œa couple of daysâ€ before the attack of the dog â€œraging and 
  rearing up.â€Â  The lease provision prohibiting pets in multifamily units was 
  not equivalent to a promise creating a duty on the part of Abbatiello to keep 
  the premises free from pets or vicious dogs.Â  Moreover, there is no evidence 
  Abbatiello permitted Miller to keep the dog in the multifamily unit, or knew 
  of any intention by Miller to keep a pet at his unit, at the time the lease 
  was entered into. [5]   
Our opinion in Mitchell 
  is also instructive in determining whether the lease created a duty of care 
  for Abbatiello to prevent harm by a tenantâ€™s dog.Â  Mitchell, 304 S.C. 
  at 404-05, 404 S.E.2d at 911-12.Â  In holding that the law did not impose a duty 
  on the landlord based on the circumstances present in Mitchell, we clearly 
  implied that a landlord is not liable even where a landlord has some form of 
  control, i.e., termination of the lease, over a tenantâ€™s dog.Â  But 
  see FOC Lawshe Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Intâ€™l Paper Co., 352 S.C. 408, 414, 
  574 S.E.2d 228, 231 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œIn Mitchell, this court found that 
  even though the landlord knew of the dogâ€™s viciousness, had adequate time to 
  terminate the tenantâ€™s lease, and failed to terminate the tenantâ€™s lease, the 
  landlord was not liable for the acts of the tenantâ€™s dog over which the landlord 
  had no control.â€) (emphasis added).
The trial court did not err in 
  finding the lease did not alter the common law rule that a landlord is not liable 
  to a third party for injuries caused by a tenantâ€™s dog.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing 
  analysis, the order of the trial court granting summary judgment is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  The record is unclear concerning whether Gilbert is also a tenant 
    at the apartment complex.Â  Patsy Chambers, whose mother lives in the complex, 
    stated in her affidavit that Gilbert â€œcame to my motherâ€™s house to pick upâ€ 
    her child.Â  Gilbertâ€™s affidavit merely states she was attacked â€œwhile at the 
    home of Patsy Chambersâ€™ mother.â€Â  Furthermore, Gilbertâ€™s brief states the 
    issue on appeal is whether a landlord can be liable for an injury to a â€œguestâ€ 
    inflicted by a tenantâ€™s dog.Â  However, Gilbertâ€™s complaint states she was 
    â€œtalking with a neighborâ€ when she was attacked by Millerâ€™s dog.Â  Abbatiello 
    admitted the facts as stated in Gilbertâ€™s complaint for the purposes of her 
    motion to dismiss.Â  Given our standard of review and Abbatielloâ€™s admission, 
    we resolve this ambiguity against Abbatiello and will assume the attack occurred 
    while Gilbert, a tenant, was a guest at another tenantâ€™s apartment.

 
   
    [2] Â  But see Cronin v. Chrosniak, 536 N.Y.S.2d 287 (N.Y. 
    App. Div. 1988) (finding summary judgment improperly granted to landlord where 
    landlord knew of dogâ€™s vicious propensities and had capability to remove dog 
    by terminating month-to-month lease); Vasques v. Lopez, 509 So. 2d 
    1241 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1987) (reversing a grant of directed verdict for 
    defendant landlord where the jury could have inferred actual knowledge of 
    the dogâ€™s vicious propensities and the landlordâ€™s control over the premises 
    based on the landlordâ€™s right to terminate a week-to-week tenancy and evict 
    the tenant).Â Â  

 
   [3] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 27-40-10 to -940 (1991 & 
    Supp. 2002).

 
   
    [4] Â  Dogs are referred to only in relation to their prohibition in multifamily 
    units.Â  We construe this prohibition to be only for the benefit of the landlord 
    and the prevention of a nuisance, such as a dog barking or pet odors, to the 
    adjoining lessee in a multifamily unit because the next sentence of the lease 
    provision addresses â€œcontinuous disturbances or complaints, such as odors, 
    fleas or messes caused by the pet . . . .â€Â  See Oâ€™Cain v. Oâ€™Cain, 
    322 S.C. 551, 473 S.E.2d 460 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating a private nuisance is 
    an unreasonable interference with the plaintiffâ€™s use and enjoyment of the 
    land).Â  Further support for this is found in another paragraph of the lease 
    mandating that â€œmultifamily units must maintain lower noise levels after 11:00 
    PM so as not to disturb other tenants.â€ 

 
   
    [5] Â  In this case, the only evidence of Abbatielloâ€™s knowledge of the 
    dog indicates she learned of the dog â€œa couple of daysâ€ before the attack.Â  
    This limited time period would have been insufficient for Abbatiello to have 
    evicted Miller and abated any hazard, given the record does not specify the 
    term of the lease.Â  A landlordâ€™s power to evict a tenant is restrained by 
    the statutory termination notice period.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-40-770 
    (1991) (providing for the termination of periodic tenancies by the landlord 
    after giving written notice to the tenant); see also Feister v. 
    Bosack, 497 N.W.2d 522, 525-26 (Mich. Ct. App. 1993) (â€œIf a third party 
    is injured before the landlord lawfully could have evicted the tenant, the 
    landlord cannot be liable, even if he knew about the dogâ€™s vicious nature.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John E. Miles,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Rachel M. Miles,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Jamie Lee Murdock, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3654
Heard April 7, 2003 â€“ Filed June 16, 
  2004
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled August 
  22, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Leeds Barroll, IV, of Columbia, John O. McDougall, of Sumter, 
  John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Mark Taylor, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  John E. Miles (â€œHusbandâ€) 
  brought this action seeking termination or, alternatively, reduction in his 
  alimony obligation to Rachel M. Miles (â€œWifeâ€).Â  The family court refused to 
  terminate, but did reduce Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation from $4,583 per month 
  to $2,500 per month.Â  Husband appeals.Â  We affirm.
Background
The parties married in 1962 and divorced in 1995.Â  
  As part of the divorce decree, the family court adopted a written agreement 
  between the parties in which Husband agreed to pay Wife $4,583 in monthly alimony.Â  
  The agreement further provided:

[T]he terms and conditions of this Agreement, and any Order 
  approving the same, shall not be modifiable by the parties or any Court without 
  the written consent of Husband and Wife. Â The parties specifically agree 
  that the Family Court . . . shall not have any jurisdiction to modify, supplement, 
  terminate or amend this Agreement, or the rights and obligations of the parties.Â
